description: A learned variant of phantom; from Middle English fantosme, from Old French fantosme, fantasme, from Latin phantasma, from Ancient Greek φάντασμα (phántasma). Doublet of phantom.

entries.meaning: Something seen but having no physical reality; a phantom or apparition.
examples: He declares that there seems to be no justification for regarding the phantasms of dreams as pure hallucinations; most dream-images are probably in fact illusions, since they arise from faint sense-impressions, which never cease during sleep.

entries.meaning: (philosophy) A impression as received by the senses, especially an image, often prior to any interpretation by the intellect.
